confession.devil_appearance: big man in black, hand was black as coal and seemed to have claws
confession.seduction_context: Asked about his affairs; replied that he was in a bad state and could not pay his debts. Percin said if he would renounce God he would give him enough to live and pay his creditors, but bag he gave him contained oak leaves
sabbat_activities: ate unpleasant meat which was not salted
made hail by beating water of stream with white sticks
kissed Persin's arse which seemed to be all hairy

testimony.quarrel_subject: Jean asked to borrow sickle from Jean Lyenard, but he refused saying he would not lend it to his own father for fear it would be spoiled
Asked if their small servant boy could also look after a cow for them; she worried about damage and subsequent harm, so declined
His son had taken fruit from her tree
dispute on subject he had forgotten
sold some grain to Jean, who had been discontented and said he would remember
Jean did not pay him 16 francs he owed

witnesses.name: Claudon Demenge Perrin
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: contract to remove weeds from field

testimony.quarrel_subject: making contract to remove weeds from his field, also question of child which was beaten
small daughter Laurence was guarding beasts when they strayed
owed him 4 francs for additional value of cow, but counted this against debt owed him by Jean's late father

harms_alleged.target_relationship: calf of cow he leased to Jean

witnesses.name: Agnes veuve Jean Demenge Babel
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: husband competed with Jean for herdsman post

testimony.quarrel_subject: Jean tried to outbid her late husband for post of herdsman but was unsuccessful
accused had stolen some of his fencing; caught him carrying this
refused to guard additional cow for Jean
Jean was working as harvester and shouted to Catherine to bring water; she replied her brother-in-law was coming
testimony.threat_quote: the devil might break her neck and her limbs

witnesses.name: Claudon Jean Simon
witnesses.occupation: doyen de maire en la mairie de St Margaree

testimony.quarrel_subject: Jean was in charge of flock and either by his doing or on his orders one of witness's sheep had leg broken

timeline.subject: Jean Jacques Gerardin
timeline.details: Change de Nancy agrees to torture

timeline.subject: Jean Jacques Gerardin
timeline.details: Interrogation under torture; confessed as soon as felt thumbscrews, then racked

timeline.subject: Jean Jacques Gerardin
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approves death sentence

accomplices_named.name: Demenge Thiehay
accomplices_named.context: Said he thought he might have recognized him at sabbat, had grey and red mask but knew him by his voice

prior_accusations.context: His uncle and two of his sisters had already been executed for witchcraft

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean Jacques Gerardin
notable_quotes.context: Response when refused sickle by Jean Lyenard

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean Jacques Gerardin
notable_quotes.french: le diable se mectoit en beaucoup de guise pour nuire aux personnes, qu'il endureroit beaucoup, mais qu'il ne diroit pas qu'il soit sorcier . . . et qu'il vailloit mieux faire penitence en ce monde, et qu'il n'accuseroit personne pour complice
notable_quotes.english: the devil put himself in many guises to harm people, that he would endure much, but he would not say he was a witch . . . and that it was better to do penance in this world, and he would not accuse anyone as accomplice
notable_quotes.context: Speaking to Mengeatte femme Jean Charpentier about his fears of arrest

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean Jacques Gerardin
notable_quotes.french: Vous estez tous bien sages, mais sy c'estoit moy, je ne la ferois communier, d'aultant que sy c'est faict de sortilege, il n'y aura plus moien de la guerir apres qu'elle sera communiée
notable_quotes.english: You are all very wise, but if it were me, I would not have her receive communion, because if it is made by witchcraft, there will be no more way to cure her after she has received communion
notable_quotes.context: Said when communion was brought to Catherine during illness

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean Jacques Gerardin
notable_quotes.french: il n'est pas puissant assez pour ce faire
notable_quotes.english: he is not powerful enough to do this
notable_quotes.context: Explaining why he had not sought reparation after being called thief and witch

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean Jacques Gerardin
notable_quotes.french: cela n'estoit que tromperie et ne servoit de rien
notable_quotes.english: that was only deception and was of no use
notable_quotes.context: What his master told him about holy bread or water

relationships.evidence_text: Was son of Jacques Gerardin of la Voivrelle
Was son of Jacques Gerardin of la Voivrelle and his wife Annon, from Faing-Thiery
The boy mentioned in previous deposition was her son
his son Jean had married Catherine, sister to his wife
garden behind house of her father-in-law, adjoining that of accused
As neighbour and relative of Catherine
his uncle and two of his sisters had been executed for witchcraft

economic_context.details: Jean owed 16 francs to Colas Barre. Jean's late father owed money to witness from Raves who leased cows. Jean was in bad economic state, could not pay debts (mentioned in confession). Jean tried to compete for post of herdsman but was unsuccessful. Jean sold pigs and 'regain' when he thought he was to be arrested. Jean not powerful enough to seek legal reparation when called thief and witch. Dispute over payment for removing weeds (paid a franc less than agreed).

harms_catalog.harm_description: became violently ill, died 10 or 11 days later
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Jean asked to borrow a sickle, refused

harms_catalog.harm_description: very ill, in bed for 7 weeks seeming out of his senses, felt as if there was a fly inside his head eating him
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: refused to guard additional cow, worried about damage

harms_catalog.harm_description: felt as if a fly went in by his ear so could hear nothing, lost speech, cried continually for 3 weeks
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: his son had taken fruit from her tree

harms_catalog.victim_name: horse belonging to Demenge Alix of Neufviller
harms_catalog.harm_description: died
lost a cow
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: dispute on subject he had forgotten

harms_catalog.harm_description: lost a bull
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: sold some grain to Jean, who had been discontented and said he would remember

harms_catalog.harm_description: claimed Jean had thrown powder through window so that he was 'appunaisé', could not bear to remain in room, died by fire 4 days later
fine cow lost its calf
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Jean did not pay him 16 francs he owed, while working in house as 'cousturier'

harms_catalog.harm_description: legs started to give way, died within 2 hours
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: shortly after passing Jean on way to church
harms_catalog.method_alleged: passed very close to horse, possibly touched it

harms_catalog.harm_description: lost two bullocks
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: quarrelled after making contract to remove weeds from his field, also question of child which was beaten

harms_catalog.harm_description: ill for a year
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: small daughter was guarding beasts when they strayed

harms_catalog.harm_description: thought he would die, became blind and had to be put into bed
harms_catalog.method_alleged: gave him 'mitridat' and powder like 'fleur de foing' to take in milk

harms_catalog.victim_relationship_to_witness: calf of cow he leased to Jean
harms_catalog.harm_description: fine calf born but died within 15 days
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: owed him 4 francs for additional value, counted against debt owed by Jean's late father

harms_catalog.harm_description: became ill and died in a week
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Jean tried to outbid her late husband for post of herdsman but was unsuccessful

harms_catalog.harm_description: strangled by a wolf in full daylight
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: accused had stolen some of his fencing, caught him carrying it, called him thief and witch
harms_catalog.method_alleged: as a witch Jean had been able to turn himself into a wolf

harms_catalog.harm_description: horse went lame
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: when he had deposed against Jean's uncle, heard Jean was blaming him for arrest

harms_catalog.harm_description: lost various animals
hurt his leg under a cart
illness that now lasted 7 weeks
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: refused to guard additional cow for Jean

harms_catalog.harm_description: pregnant, had trouble with a leg, after delivery languished for 10 weeks 'toute pourrie' up to the waist before she died
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Jean was working as harvester and shouted to her to bring water; she replied her brother-in-law was coming
harms_catalog.method_alleged: cursed that the devil might break her neck and her limbs

harms_catalog.harm_description: sheep had leg broken, but recovered after Jean tied up leg
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Jean was in charge of flock and either by his doing or on his orders one of witness's sheep had leg broken

harms_catalog.harm_description: became blind and had head all swollen

expecting to be arrested at any time

reproaches_to_witnesses.objection: Mengeon Thiehay had been taken to justice because he made exorbitant charges as guardian of his sisters; Thiehay said he had not been fined, which showed charges were false

extraction_metadata.notes: Trial w269 of Jean Jacques Gerardin. Complete extraction from 7-page PDF. All 30 witnesses documented. Accused confessed under torture to witchcraft including sabbat attendance, making hail, and various acts of maleficia. Uncle and two sisters previously executed for witchcraft. Economic hardship and debt prominent themes. Executed November 29, 1611.
